review: I bought this gadget not doing my fair share of research. I was lead to believe its biggest selling point was the fact that I would be able to cast web content from my phone/tablet. This does not seem to be the case at all. I've read there are beta apps/programs that work on a user by user basis. If I would have figured out that its best use what using your phone/tablet to select a movie/video from standard apps (Netflix, Hulu, Hbogo, etc) then I probably would have stuck with a roku. That being said, the price point is very attractive. And so far I've had not issues with its performance on the compatible apps. Normally I'd bring this thing back for a refund, but for the cost (and more importantly, its potential future upgrades) I will hold on to it. If nothing else it is an excellent (and fairly priced) alternative for what is out there. I cant help but get the feeling that google has more in store for the future of this device. If not then I'm out a few $$ that I could easily waste on other things that serve no purpose at all. At the very least I can do the standard streaming services with a very small footprint. My biggest point is, dont expect to open a browser on your phone or tablet and simply stream/send it to your tv. When and if that day comes this little powerhouse will have a huge market. Overall I'd still recommend getting it if you do not run a plex server or something similar. It is somewhat nice and fun to pick your movies/shows on your phone and send them to your tv. Youtube/Music/Movies seem to work without a hitch.

review: I've owned a Chromecast since it came out, literally one of the best purchases of my life. I can stream anything I want to it, literally anything. The best part is the Plex support, I don't even need to get on my desktop to get this baby working(yes, Netflix too, but Netflix is obviously limited). I would recommend this to anyone and everyone, best deal for anything video streaming wise.Oh also very customizable now, you can change the backgrounds to whatever you want.
